SENT.plain: Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common sustained arrhythmia that is associated with significant morbidity and mortality
Current available therapies remain inadequate in symptom control and secondary prevention and are often associated with significant side effects
The mechanisms underlying the pathogenesis of AF are poorly understood, although electrophysiological remodeling has been described as an important initiating step
Recently, increasing evidence implicates oxidative stress and inflammation in the pathogenesis of AF
We searched the literature for evidence to support the use of antioxidant vitamins C and E in the prevention of AF
These vitamins, through their reactive-oxygen-species- (ROS-) scavenging effect, have shown a role in AF prevention in both animal and small clinical studies
The available evidence, however, is currently insufficient to support recommendations for their use in the wider patient population
Larger-scale clinical studies are required to confirm these preliminary results
Research is also required to further the understanding of the processes involved in the pathogenesis of AF and the role of antioxidant therapies to prevent the arrhythmia
